adjective.description: Having or showing a willingness to act dishonestly in return for money or personal gain.
examples: unscrupulous logging companies assisted by corrupt officials

adjective.description: (of a text or a computer database or program) made unreliable by errors or alterations.
(of organic or inorganic matter) in a state of decay; rotten or putrid.

verb.description: Cause to act dishonestly in return for money or personal gain.
examples: there is a continuing fear of firms corrupting politicians in the search for contracts

verb.description: Change or debase by making errors or unintentional alterations.
examples: Epicurus's teachings have since been much corrupted

origin: Middle English: from Latin corruptus, past participle of corrumpere mar, bribe, destroy, from cor- altogether + rumpere to break.
